This truly is one of the best sci-fi action games ever made. It combines FPS (there's a TPS view too though) and RTS. It's light on the RTS part, but there is just enough to make it fun in that department too while not bogging down those who aren't fans of RTS.

The action is really really good! You drive a hover tank and it's great! The hover tanks controls amazingly as you zoom across the battlefield and strafe your enemies while pumping them full of lead and plasma. The terrain is hardly an obstacle for you, so make sure to use it to your advantage.

The campaign has a very interesting story and takes you to different planets and moons in our solar system. At times the missions can be very challenging, but they have managed to strike the perfect balance by putting missions with less pressure in between those that has you sweating bullets.

The gameplay and graphical user interface (that radar is awesome) goes far beyond what I'd expect from a game from '98. I played the old version of the game too, so I know that those things aren't simply improved by the remake. They were always that great!

I highly recommend playing this game!

37992864.review:
TL;DR: You will duck in your computer chair, lob mortars into an enemy base for lulz, and fight on foot to kill an enemy.

The best game I've ever played that combines RTS and FPS. The action is like Homeworld meets Battlefield 4, and it's a damn good marriage. Battles are fierce, especially when resources become scarce. Unit capabilties are all different, from weapons to manueverability along with the many different weapons you can equip. The multiplayer is fantastic, I've never had an "easy" game and the community is fun to play against. From players trying to snipe during a large battle with rockets and freaking laser beams going everywhere, to dropping a mega bomb at your foes base entrance to weaken the defences, there is no safe space. You will have your weakpoints exploited fiercly and deal with head to head combat when it comes to getting resources. People will treat it like gold, and rightfully so. I remember my bombers getting whipped by a fleet of scouts that flanked me -- but the balance is so well implemented with speed vs firepower, that I barely won the fight. I retreated after my victory, ammoless, only to be taken out by a few scouts chasing me.

My fondest memory was when I was literally ducking in my computer chair when a ship flew over me while I was attacking a small enemy outpost, which got ugly quickly when it became clear it was a trap. I recall knowing it was likely a trap, my ally said I'd regret chasing the bait, and even my cat said not to do it, but there's nothing more pleasing than chasing and shooting a ship running away from you if it means getting some scrap and downing one potential attacker.

There are so many ways to play the game, and so many ways to counter an enemy tactic. Each encounter is different, some more brutal than others. Such as both enemies going at it, blowing each other up, getting ejected high into the air, then floating downward towards each other to finish the fight ON FOOT. These are the moments arenas full of people would get tense over, someone will get laser beamed to death or sniped in the brawl -- perhaps by a mutual enemy watching from the sideline? Or some random ass scavenger came by making its way to drop off scrap, and creamed one of the players on accident. 

Yup, welcome to Battlezone.

35976899.review:
An absolute classic.

I replayed this game wanting to relive a game from my childhood, and was wondering to see how it held up. And...it did! Mostly thanks to the remastering it was given. The AI was updated, the graphics were given a nice smoothing out polish that stays true to the original game while giving it its own appeal all on its own.

The Campaigns are great. The base two that is, the expansion is another beast. The story is a fascinating concept I've yet to see anyone pull off quite as well. The Space Race was a cover to launch a new fleet of ships to gather a mysterious but powerful metal that fell to Earth in a meteor shower. America and the Soviet Union are spreading throughout the Solar System to find this new material, and slowly discover its not so benign origins.

Although it could be seen as basic in some ways, the writing and voice acting sell this story. Every VA is giving this story their fullest, and still maintains a strange sense of authenticity despite some lines or accents that are fairly cheesy in nature. The Soviets in particular are great in this regard.

The balance between the two isn't too difficult, the NSDF are a bit faster, the CCA are a bit tougher, and they share all the same units. Despite this they still manage to feel unique thanks to the great designs, and weapon loadouts. You have the ability to change loadouts as well once you have an armory, giving you any of the weapons in the game for just a bit of scrap. You can use units as they are and do great, or customize their weaponry and do even better! Or worse depending on what you give them, but still.

The difficulty is just right, as the campaign can be fairly challenging at times on the tougher difficulties, but thankfully a good strategy can carry you through the game. There's no times that not knowing what comes ahead in the mission will screw you over, and any mission that you lose will just about always be your fault, save for maybe one Soviet mission. You'll know it when you get to it.

If you're looking for the original RTS/FPS Combination, this is it baby. Great gameplay, Great story, Great voice acting, Great everything. The only gripes I would have are the AI are a bit too good at tracking your every moment before you make it, some missions are definitely stacked against the player and are a little frustrating, and ...Really that's it.

9/10 Spores, easily. Not perfect, but definitely close.

For $20, you will definitely get your money's worth.

Avoid the expansion though.

34895353.review:
THE LEGACY IS BAAAAAAAAACK!!!!!!!!

I cannot stress how happy I am with this game. I've been playing (not to mention making mods for) the Battlezone franchise since my childhood, and while BZ2 expanded and improved on the original in almost every way the original Battlezone holds a special place in my heart, forever and always. And I am positively thrilled to report that this reboot is the very same Battlezone I came to adore back in the 2000's, albeit with improved graphics and performance.

Now, an un-biased review!

First off, graphics. The graphics are, indeed, more than a little dated. This still looks like the game that came out in 1998. That's not to say that it looks bad or anything. It just don't hold up compared to modern games, so if you're looking for something as gorgeous as Crysis 3 you'd best look elsewhere. The reboot did do a wonderful job of reworking the terrain and textures, giving the game sharper details and clearer imagery while keeping the retro look and feel of the original.

Next, gameplay. Where to freakin' start?! Not much has changed between the original and the reboot in this department. Gameplay is the original fast-paced RTS/Shooter hybrid, centering around the fleet of hovertanks you have at your disposal. Build a base, gather resources, build and command your army, all while dogfighting with enemy forces behind the controls of any one of the numerous vehicles at your disposal, from quick and nimble scout craft to meaty tanks to lumbering and terrifying walkers. Outfit your vehicle and your wingmen with a selection of conventional and futuristic weapons like anti-tank cannons, heat-seeking missiles, lasers, or that damn Thumper (an earthquake gun of all things).

The controls are rather intuitive for such a hybrid game. Sure, there are a few things that might throw off modern gamers (using E to jump and your spacebar to command units, i.e.), but once you get the hang of it the controls handle quite nicely. The UI is decent enough, with your units divided into catagories that you then select from (Offensive for things like tanks, Defensive for turrets and howitzers, utility for gatherers and such, ect.). The system is a bit limited but works smoothly enough with the gameplay.

All in all I HIGHLY reccomend this game to anyone looking to try something new. Battlezone plays like nothing else out on the market, and while an RTS/FPS hybrid does take some getting used to it is well worth a try. It may have aged a bit and might not look as good as current-gen AAA games, but this is one sleeper that will grab a willing player by the throat and keep them begging for more.

34563432.review:
Absolutely the best computer game ever written - here with a beautiful face lift. No other game ever came close to combining a first person shooter, inside a real time strat with online play.  The flight mechanics were always fantastic, and you'd have fun just flying arounf the moon and doing sideway slides, but combined with such a clever and intuitive user interface Battlezone really hit all of the marks. The only thing that was ever wrong with Battlezone, was that because it was an unusual mix - most people never even tried it.

So this is what it is.

Imagine a strat game - in the style of things like command and conquer, or something where you're building resources and one or more enemies is as well. Now imagine that instead of being a god like figure looking down on that game, you're actually inside it. You can run around, jump into vehicles, eject and so on - but more importantnly you can still command an array of ships and resources as the battle rages around you - almost as simply as pointing at something. 

The AI of your ships and enemy ships is great and large battles can unfold - but then take that online - and suddenly you have a dozen people all doing this in a strat game, or simply battling it our like a roman gladiator. 

In the last 20 years this game is still unsurpassed in the in game user interface, flight mechanics, first person strat - and potential for online fun

34155095.review:
This and Battlezone II were some of my favorite games as a kid, and I'm so very glad the series is once again getting some attention!

The core mechanics of this game remain unchanged from the original. Which is good, as they (mostly) still hold up 19 years later. Zipping around in your tank of choice still feels good, as if the vehicles have weight to them. Weapons still have a punch. Commanding multiple units is still easy enough to figure out from the start, though doesn't get much more in-depth than what you get at the surface.

As for the remake, almost all of the changes have been cosmetic. Upgraded textures, visual effects, some touches to lighting. A proper, full-on remake could have seen multiple Quality of Life changes, or changes to things like the shape of terrain, additional units/buildings, or changes to the way pilot movement and combat functions. I just wish Big Boat Interactive had done [i]more[/i].

As it stands, it seems as though this project was given to a small team to test waters, and the new Battlezone VR game appears to have been the focus of Rebellion's use of the IP. The game is still fun, and I'm eager to see what else they have in store for the series.

BATTLEZONE IS AWESOME.  It has always been awesome, and this Redux version does a great job of breathing new life into it.  When it comes to these nostalgic remasters and remakes, sometimes I have a hard time determining if a game was truly great, or just seemed great at the time and I was too young to really know the difference.  Rest assured, Battlezone deserves its legendary status.  

Playing this game reminds you how great gaming can be, and why you've been a gamer all this time.  Most games have obvious inspiration from other titles, and generally follow the same formula within their genre.  Battlezone is a true original, there are very few games even remotely similar.  It's still the best FPS/RTS hybrid, and one of the best RTS games of all time.  The controls are unique, but instantly intuitive and very effective.  I don't understand why nobody has even attempted cloning BZ over the years.   

All in all I'm very happy this "redux" version was made, and very happy I picked it up.  Battlezone would have been a legend in my memory either way, but nobody should miss this chance to relive one of gaming's true gems.

33154490.review:
This nostalgia galore. Battlezone revived for modern computer systems! This is a dream come true for fans of this classic. 

If you played the old Battlezone from 1998, this will feel very familiar to you. The sights and sounds are practically the same, but the graphics are upgraded from the original release. There is little reason to not get the Red Odyessy as well. 



If you haven't played Battlezone before, here is the basic premise: 

In 1952, a metor shower rains down around the Bering Strait between Alaska and the USSR. The meteor remains, which are collected by the US and the Soviets, contain strange material that is named Bio-Metal. This material allows both superpowers to be able to make massive leaps in thier technology, far beyond even today's tech, although the general public is kept in the dark. 

Fast forward to 1969, and the Apollo 11 mission lands on the moon, Basically the Space Race as we know it still happens as a cover. The real space race is what the story focuses on. Before Apollo happens, the US has already established a military presence on the moon, using very advanced technology and vehicles derrived from the Bio-Metal. In fact, during the first mission, you see one of the Lunar landers.  

However, the USSR also lands military forces on the moon, called the Communist Cosmonaut Army (CCA) on the moon, and attack the US forces, which are called the National Space Defense Force (NSDF).   The story takes off from there, with missions taking place around the planets and moons of the solar system, not Earth though.  There is also a campaign where you play as one of the Soviets. 

Additionally, the Red Odyessy DLC, back then called an expansion pack, takes place on Ganyemede, one of Jupiter's moons, with the NSDF fighting the People's Republic of China, which has also obtained Bio-metal from meteors. Their space forces are called the Chinese Red Army (CRA). The Chinese have there own unique units, and are not completely allied with the Soviets, reflecting the real life Sino-Soviet split. There is one campaign for each side in this DLC as well. 

The game itself is a hybrid of real time strategy/tactics and first person vehicle combat. 

You control your vehicle and it's weapons, taking part in combat, but also command friendly units, as well as building bases and collecting Bio-Metal (the only resource, which can be found scattered about the maps or can be taken from the wreckage of destroyed units). 

Each side has a variety of vehicles, which you can change during a level. Hitting the 'H' key has you hop out of your vehicle and able to get in another one. You also eject automatically when your vehicle is destoryed. While outside the vehicle, you are basically an Astronaut infantryman with a plasma rifle. You are extremely vulnerable in this state.  So get in another vehicle ASAP.

Don't fool yourself, This is a challenging game. This is from a time when games were more challenging to complete. 

If you are up for a challenge and want to try something different from more recent games, get this and enjoy yourselves!

32755859.review:
Whether you are a US Astronaut piloting a Grizzly or a USSR Cosmonaut piloting a Golem, this is a review from when I started training up to the Mars missions.
Story: As an United States-based NSDF commander known only as Grizzly One, your assignment was to protect the Moon from the invasion of the Soviet-based CCA invasion, ultimately failing, but getting everyone evacuated in time. Now, you have to go to Mars to establish a base among the CCA already stationed there, until you find evidence of an ancient alien race and their ancient tech that could make or break space forever. As a time piece game, it's a "Cold War-gone-Hot" based game with some 1984-level cleansing to make sure the public never knows and, to be fair, it's one of the better games to execute the story. 9/10
Graphics: The graphics look pretty damn awesome. Playing it from a N64 version, the graphical advantage is apparent and it does do a lot of what it needs to do in order to be a redeluxe version of the 1998 classic. 9/10
Controls: To me, the tanks control like lubed up bananas on a wax floor like they participated in the Indy 500 (which does make sense considering they're hovering tanks), but the controls for ordering your troops or base around to any potential power source works well enough. 8/10
Music and Sound: Both are recycled from the original '98 version, but it would have been cool if the voice lines were updated with new voice actors, but add in the touches needed to make it sound like the originals. While I could just leave it at a 6.5/10 and get on with it, the fact that the music and a lot of the in-game sound can be replaced with mods is the reason I'll give it a 7.5/10.
Overall and mentions: As a person who has only seen footage of Battlezone 98 and had some trouble with Rise of the Black Dogs on the N64, I was disappointed to see how such a hyped game resulted in something relatively obscure. It's not exactly a diamond in the rough, but it is definitely something like a ruby in the rough. I hope that it does get more players, though most people will still decide to download the original 1998 game. 7.5/10 because it's not a bad game, but it does have some issues that could make it overlooked. However, I still would like to recommend it to people so they can try it out for themselves.

31750926.review:
I played this game on an old Compaq Presario in the 1990's.  I then had the luxury of playing this patched and modified variant on a modern machine.  I have to say, it was a great improvement.  I played online and had a blast.  It was a fun beer night.  If you are looking at this title, you likely played it a long time ago, and if you liked it then, you will like it now.  People do jump in online from time to time, but be prepared to get stomped.

If you are new to the series, and somehow looking for old games, this title is great.  The graphics are upgraded slightly from what they were a long time ago.  The game is stable enough to run on modern machines and OS, and the multiplayer works.  The story is a cliche 1980's cold war saga, but with a twist that the USA and USSR are fighting a secret war in space.  What sets this game apart, however, is that it is one of the first games that combined first person shooter with base building and unit controlling RTS, AND did it relatively well.  There are a handful of games that had this style back then, but Battlezone 98 definitely ranks up there as one of the better ones.  You can jump in and out of your vehicles, build a base, build new vehicles, mine stuff, order battle groups around, or have them follow you, and pilot your way to glory.  There are plenty of vehicles to choose from, and the tech progression works up nicely.  A real classic Command and Conquer feel, with a first person 3d twist.  My only gripe is that this game isn't remade in Unreal or Unity 3d.  This game is a blast.

29264046.review:
Where do we begin...

Battlezone 98 was a game far ahead of its time.  When first person shooters and strategy games were still in larval stages while platformers and other genres dominated the market, this game brilliantly blended the two bold new genres together in a format unlike any other.  Not only did you build buildings and commanded armies, you went on the frontlines with them with powerful tanks, and if you were feeling lucky, you can disembark one for REAL sniper skill challenges as a humble trooper.  They have a wonderful mix of both units, and arsenals that can shake the game up faster than a bartender on crack mixing a martini.

The primary drawbacks i site on this is the lack of open ended skirmish both offline and online, if they did this like other strategy games did back in the day this game would be perfect, and resources are very finite making gameplay restrictive.  The game is very challenging but can be a real controller/mouse to the screen difficult, and not in the challenging way that uber gamers desire, more like, "WHY THE FUCK!? HOW!?" where you can only have a margin in the lower single digits of error to proceed.

The game had immense potential, and it still does, but as long as the gameplay remains this restrictive it won't go further than it is.  Despite the flaws, i still recommend this hidden gem to anyone seeking a witches brew of intense first person shooting combat and calculating real time strategy gameplay molded into one.  Cold War in space yo! Fight with alien tech mang!

28820901.review:
[b]Battlezone 98 Redux[/b] is a rehash of an old classic from 1998, brought to STEAM by Rebellion, a company behind such titles as [b]Sniper Elite[/b] or [b]Aliens versus Predator[/b] [1999, 2010].

[b]Battlezone[/b] is a hybrid style game, a crossover between first person view vehicle combat shooter [FPS for short] and a real time strategy [RTS]. Does that mix do the job? Yes and no. What is certainly lacking is a [i]pause-and-command[/i] button, minding the FPS element is often intense, leaving very little time to make grand strategic decisions. But whether playing [b]Command and Conquer[/b] you have ever thought if it was you in one of those tanks, you'd show'em, here you go, [b]Battlezone[/b] is all about that and it is tough as nails.

The game is a true classic, reminding me of [b]UFO Enemy Unknown[/b] [1993] in many aspects. [b]Battlezone[/b] and [b]UFO[/b] are both innovative, experimenting and focused on multilayer management. Both also represent core science-fiction. While [b]UFO[/b] is yet turn-based and general level, [b]Battlezone[/b] is real-time and down to the gunbattle.

[b]Battlezone[/b] is definitely a gem of its time, probably even beyond its time, probably even beyond any time before or after its release, so to say. It is just a unique product. How does it stand nowadays? How playable it ultimately is at the present?

That is when things come down to the rating, which unfortunately is negative. STEAM review must be either recommending or dissuading. With greatest difficulty I see this game appealing to modern [2016] players. The problem is more than just nature of visuals or lacking of certain ease elements, such as the mentioned [i]pause-and-command[/i] function. It is the oftentimes chaotic picture of action, difficulty of FPS combat and movement controls, overall difficulty level, complex real-time base and force management with flaws characteristic to the early productions standing for the RTS genre.

The score is 5/10 wHATs grade. I should best repeat what has already been put in one of the other customers reviews: if you are prone to like this game, you probably already know it, thus have little need for any reviews to help you make up your mind about the purchase. Otherwise, if you hesitate, skip it.

What is needed with [b]Battlezone[/b], is a complete remake [reboot], reintroducing the game to the modern public, instead of only a visual facelift [redux]. Currently it is a niche release, addressed towards the veterans of original version.

27982215.review:
I remember playing this game back in 98, it was the first ever PC game I remember playing. So having said that I preface with nostalgia having a factor here. The game looks pretty good for it's age, and unlike other games I have, playing on my 65" tv isn't haveing any effect on the games frames.

Pros: 
A very interesting story
Interesting units and tactics to play them
Two sepereate campaigns with provide their own challenges
Good blend of FPS tank fights, with a healthy blend of RTS you can't forget about
Simple and direct inputs mean you can just a few buttons quickly and get tasks done
Looks great (for being originally from 98), and still plays pretty well
Back in the day, the multiplayer was pretty fun, but it's been awhile since I played that

Cons:
Sometimes the AI is dumb as a sack of potatoes...
...When they aren't being dumb, they kick your ass.
In game doesn't really tell you nearly ANYTHING you need to know about how to play other than move and shoot, so expect to go to outside sources to learn how to do more complex manuevers, commands, and tactics.
Unit limits - you can have 10 units from three categories (offense, defense, utility) so it's not quite a massive strat game as some others. 
Expect your units to have no self preservation skills, and they don't always like being called back to retreat either.

So if the cons seemed a bit heavy, its because I want to be honest in this review. If you like RTS games, and like what you see it is worth it. The way the game feels even today is smooth and just like I recall from nearly two decades ago, whereas normally nostalgia games don't live up to their memory this one most certainly does indeed. Coming back to it as an adult I wonder how I ever played this as a kid, and where it's been all my adult life.

26202035.review:
Now THIS was a major venture down Memory lane in Nostalgia City for me.
I do not know how many hours I clocked on this back when I was 10 and up, my very first proper PC game, FPS experience.
Back then I did not understand English, so it took me about 12 (perhaps less) restarts off the same initial mission before I realized that it used WASD to move and not the arrow keys.

I remember not understanding that the spacebar is the interaction button that also commands turrets to deploy on a specific location of my choice.
So my turrets would fly around me "ring around the rosie" style and block my view, I remember using the jump button to gain a little bit of height in order to shoot over my "human shield" of turrets.

I remember finally figuring out how the game worked, finally making buildings and progressing through a campaign I did not understand, but now that I understand the pre-mission voice-diaries and the mission logs you can read after each mission, the lore and story is.. decent, compared to plenty of today's games.
However, considering just how many memories this sparked for me, it was easily worth the price, especially with the extremely challenging Red Odyssey campaign.

Nevermind the multiplayer that will challenge you harshly considering some people who buy this game are old die-hards who played it since 1998

I recommend Battlezone 98 Redux to anyone who wants a rather simplistic yet decently deep campaign for it's simplicity, and possibly want to learn a new FPS/RTS multiplayer which will undoubtedly challenge you harshly since some of those who play this have played it since 1998.

Enjoy!

25740372.review:
Where it says "# hours on record", that should really be measured in years. I grew up playing this game, and have always come back to it.

Engaging gameplay hybridizing real time strategy and 1st/3rd person hovertank combat! This game is nothing like anything else we have today, it's still extremely unique and I hope we get another sequel soon.

The story is a unique historical Cold War timeline spin-off involving the discovery of biometal (a sentient material) as well as alien relics in the solar system,  by the Americans and the Soviets, all in the midst of a Cold War back on Earth. Nobody else from Earth knows this is going on.

The space environments are super immersive. Visuals, sound, control scheme, everything is a masterpiece of an experience.

Fly massive hovertanks on the moon, hop out as a small, vulnerable pilot and fly high with a jetpack, crouch on the edge of cliffs and snipe enemy ships to hijack them. Defend outposts on the lunar surface, soar through canyons on Mars and climb Olympus Mons, strafe under enemy fire, order artillery and turrets to defend points, command fleets of scout and tank crafts to patrol, hunt, and attack enemy positions. Scavenge for scrap and biometal geysers with which to construct your fully-mobile base structures and units, deploy awesome weapons and powerup your ships with advanced equipment... send earthquakes across the terrain and blast hostile ships caught spinning into the air!

I'm so happy this old gem has been repolished. 
It's my favorite game of all time; it inspired me to make my game One Giant Leap. Now we just need Battlezone in VR!

I've played this game and been a part of the 1.5 patch/Online forum community since 2011. I modded heavily, made dozens of maps, participated in strat tournaments, and was a very loyal BZ player for years (alias: Ian S.) Unfortunately, I got away from BZ in school when life happened, but now over the summer I've come to try the Redux.

This is a bit of an emotional game for me. My brother and I played it when I was 4, on an old Windows 95 machine. I found the game again when I was 14 and lonely, and absolutley immersed myself in modding and making maps, learning about every trick in the book to script missions. When LUA coding came out, my entire modding world was opened.

As far as the game goes, as advertised it's an awesome blend of the FPS/RTS genre. I've always appreciated how you can control and mobilize an entire army of vehicles but still zoom around in a tank blowing up crap. The campaigns are epic in this game, especially the NSDF one. There are some elements from BZ 1.5 (before the Redux came out) that I like better, but overall the Redux is much higher quality and transitions the game into the 21st century. Online multiplayer is also very fun, there is nothing quite like winning a strategy match after an adrenaline-pumping half an hour of back and forth combat.

I can't put as much effort into this game as I wish I could anymore, but I do highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't tried it before. It's classic but now new, with a small but very solid community supporting it, so you can't go wrong!

It's quite a change from BZII in some ways, but it's enough the same that adapting to these differences was easy enough, and boy was it worth it. The gameplay is so nostalgic it almost hurts (I shamelessly admit I did cry a little when I first started playing), and it helped patch holes in the story for me, having only played BZII prior.

It's a fun challenge, and, as far as I'm aware, a rather unique style of gameplay that I've never really seen replicated outside of BZII (the combination of the RTS base-building, unit-commanding with the FPS player-controlled unit is an element I just love to bits, yet I can't think of any other games that utilize it).

Would I recommend the game? Most definitely, even if just to try it out! Sure, nothing is for everyone, but as they say, "Nothing ventured, nothing gained"!

Absolut genial, wie lange habe ich dieses Spiel vermisst und jetzt ist es auf einmal zurück in überarbeiteter Fassung. 

Man kann sich im Command & Conquer Stil eine Basis aufbauen mit allen möglichen Gebäuden wie zum Beispiel eine Fahrzeug Werft, Truppen Baracken, Energie oder Rohstoff Förderer und noch einiges mehr. Das Ganze findet im Gegensatz zu Command & Conquer in einer 3D Umgebung Stadt. 

Große Karten bzw. Maps auf denen es viel zu entdecken gibt machen das ganze interessant vor allem für Spieler mit einem Entdeckerkomplex so wie ich einer bin. Die Handlung spielt stets auf fremden Planeten oder Monden wie zum Beispiel unserem Mond oder dem Mars. Viele Planeten und Monde unseres Sonnensystems sind vertreten.

Man kontrolliert das ganze Geschehen in seiner Basis direkt in dem man entweder zu Fuss dort herumläuft und alles Steuert oder in dem man in ein Fahrzeug einsteigt und vom Cockpit aus alles baut regelt und Steuert usw.

Bei einer Schlacht kann man selbstverständlich auch ganz vorne mit dabei sein wenn man möchte. Entweder kann man zu Fuß an der Schlacht teilnehmen oder von Cockpit seines Fahrzeuges aus mit kämpfen.

Die umgebungen beziehungsweise die Landschaften in denen alles stattfindet sind für die damalige Zeit in der das Spiel entstanden ist wunderschön gemacht und haben auch heute, vor allem in dieser überarbeiteten Version, nichts von ihrem Charme verloren.

Ich finde Grafik- Sound- und Gameplay technisch alles 1A, das einzige was dem Spiel noch fehlt sind mehr Mitspieler für tolle Multiplayerschlachten. 

Ich kann das Spiel wirklich nur empfehlen und für diesen kleinen Preis ist es wirklich ein Tipp.

24532332.review:
[h1]情怀[/h1]
当年在PII 233Hz 32MB内存的机器上玩到的第一款3D游戏。没想到快20年了，现在又能体验到这种激动人心的感觉。

[h1]特点[/h1]
这是一款独特的主视角RTS，十分硬核。你既要操作飞船跟敌人战斗，同时又需要控制建筑、单位的建造，甚至还需要分别给每个单位下达指令。要做的事情太多，所以难免手忙脚乱。而且因为无法纵观全局，所以难免顾此失彼。

主视角部分也十分硬核。首先你是一个驾驶员。你可以下飞船，也可以在飞船快爆炸的时候弹射出去。驾驶员还有两种武器突击步枪和狙击枪。。。这游戏里不存在能锁定目标的武器，瞄准敌人对我来说已经是个不小的考验。

[h1]总结[/h1]
这游戏就是给98年玩过前作的老炮儿们玩。那个时代的游戏在有些设定上还是不怎么人性化，操作习惯跟现在游戏也不太一样。需要适应，挺虐的。没有情怀也不准备被虐的朋友请慎重考虑。

24528249.review:
As someone who has been with this game since childhood, I cannot recommend it enough. This remaster remains incredibly faithful to the original vision, keeping what worked and only improving what needed to be improved. With dozens of new features for modders and map makers to play with, support for all the original community content, and visuals enhanced by none other than the game's original lead artist Carey Chico. There isn't much else one can say, having been with the game so long, than that this remaster should be a gold standard for all other companies looking to revitalize older games.

Call me biased, but I love this game, and as other community veterans will shun this remaster as being "too different" from the game they remember, I can honestly find very little bad to say about it, certainly nothing that would fit in a short review.

I give this remaster a 9/10, and hope to give it a perfect 10 as future patches and both official and community content smooth over the few remaining rough edges.

A good revival of an old, but good classic - hot soviet-on-american space tanks vs. space tanks action (and strategy)!
I'm a big fan of the '98 original, so I'll make the comparison based on that.
What has changed:
-Graphics: especially the textures. Gives the original the botox treatment it needed, but not too much eye-popping. (Depending on much you've played the original.)
-HUD: finally scales with screen resolution, though purists might argue that it's not 100% the same.
-Modding support: Steam Workshop integration, yay!
-Multiplayer support
What hasn't:
-Gameplay: if your think that the redux will change any bigger gameplay elements, you will be in for a dissappointment.
-Sounds: Again, no major, noticeable changes. Music is the same, unit voices are the same. ("Die, you commie pinkoes!" FTW)
Note: it doesn't include the Red Odyssey expansion.
Overall: a must-buy if you're a fan of the original, a possible should-buy if you want interested in how an arcade tank shooter - real-time strategy mix would work, or want some retro-futuristic space Cold War butt-kicking.

Battlezone was very unique for its time when it came out with its blend of RTS and FPS as well as its interesting take on the Cold War and that there was actually a war going on, not on Earth but in space where USA and the USSR duke it out in highly advanced hover vehicles made from a strange substance dubbed Bio Metal.

Rebellion did an excellent job at creating this redux version of Battlezone with its improved visuals as well as support for Steam Workshop mods, there are already plenty of nice mods for players to try out including new maps for you and friends to duke it out on in multiplayer.

22723985.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Battlezone 98 Redux is set in a alternative version of 1960s whereby the USA and Soviet Union have secretly deployed armies into space for an extra-terrestrial substance that can be forged to craft weapons and armour that is powerful. Obviously other Nations are going to fight over this substance, so the National Space Dfence Force and  Cosmos Colonist Army battle over control of this substance.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This game is a blend of RTS and FPS elements that really seem to fit together and join together as one rather well. With the game primarily taking place in space with a sort of futuristic style it really takes upon the genre rather well. You can play as a hover tank that you can view from the cockpit, hunting down enemys with the hovertank destorying enemy crafts is rather satifying and brings back memories of when I used to play Starwars battlefront II.

Although the game looks rather nice and seems like a pretty strong build from the earlier version of the game, sometimes the AI on the game seems a bit unresponsive and just sits there. Sometimes their pathfinding of where they are actually suppose to be moving can be a bit weird and obserdly different than what you would expect them to do.

Anyways, the game is a really good source of what a RTS game should be all about. Being able to deploy your recycler at a power source to collect bio-metal that are used in the base in order to build defensive structers and wingmen into the battle. You are able to build towers to help you in the battle, with things such as Comm Tower which can take control of a satellite and you are able to view the battlezone. This gives you the added advantage of being able to command your wingmen in the traditional wya that you would normally in other RTS games.

With the graphics remasterd from the 1998 version of the game, it looks very nice and sharp which is what you would expect a game to look like in todays standards. With the hovercrafts and towers looking very futuristic and nicely detailed, I feel like the game was refinely detailed in every way when this game was being developed. The textures look very smooth and the explosions on are very nice.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Detailed graphics
+ Fun gameplay
+ Shows what a RTS should rally be like
+ FPS in a RTS game is very unique and hard to come by on steam

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Weird AI at times

[h1]Result / Final Thoughts[/h1]
My final thoughts on this game are pretty high. They really took the original game and made it into a modern version, with the graphics of everything and the amount of towers you can build to help you win the battle it really shows what you can do with a RTS game. If you can get past the weird AI at times, then I would definatly recommened this game.

[b]Rating: 8.2/10[/b]

22697070.review:
This is the best game you've never played. It's the hidden gem of hidden gems.

Set in an alternate 1960s where the space race is just a cover for a cold war turned hot, the United States and Soviet Union secretly deploy massive armies into space in pursuit of an extra-terrestrial substance, [i]bio-metal[/i], that can be used to craft amazing and powerful weapons of war. The National Space Defense Force (NSDF) and Cosmos Colonist Army (CCA) do battle over control of the [i]bio-metal[/i] throughout the solar system using hover tanks crafted from the precious material. Battlezone has some of the best sci-fi lore of any game- don't skip over the briefings and debriefings! 

Battlezone has always had interesting gameplay because of the way it blends RTS and FPS elements. You primarily play the game from the view of the cockpit of your hover tank: you can hunt down enemy craft yourself and blow them away, OR, you can deploy your [i]recycler[/i] (main production unit) at a nearby geyser power source and being collecting [i]bio-metal[/i] using [i]scavengers[/i] in order to build a base, defensive structures, and wingmen to take into battle with you. If you build a Comm Tower, you can take a satellite view of the battle[strike]field[/strike]zone and command your wingmen in traditional RTS style, but you don't need to have a Comm Tower to effectively command all of your units (in fact, most often it is better to NOT take this approach).

Battlezone 98 Redux (BZR) has received many improvements over the original game. These include highly improved terrain textures, models, lighting, menus, and more, and these alone make the game worth a purchase and play through. However, because BZR is built on the code of the 1998 release, some of the baggage from years ago has made its way into this game. The net code, though improved, still struggles from time to time, and having a good connection can be important to having an enjoyable online experience. (Overall this is has never been a problem for me, though.) The sound system also struggles mightily when there are many units in play or in a battle- it will eventually just choke and cut out completely until there are fewer units. The sound cutting out is a scenario that you're for the most part unlikely to encounter during regular gameplay, however.

Keeping these small qualms in mind, the game is absolutely a steal at its current price, and will buy you hours and hours of fun in space. I SAID FUN IN SPACE!

If any 90's game deserved a Redux, this was it. Especially if you never played the original (but even if you have!), this is a must buy.

10 Grizzlies out of 10.

22617172.review:
Battlezone was released back in 1998 and was one of the first action-RTS hybrids - it has all the usual elements of an RTS, but you command from the ground in a vehicle, fighting alongside your troops. The genre never really took off, but because Battlezone was bundled with a lot of graphics cards it reached a wide audience and gained a cult following.

If you are someone who's considering buying this having played it way back when, do it. It's a reworking, not a remake, so the real BZ atmosphere is still there. The ships and buildings are all heavily redone, with much more detailed models and much larger textures. They look excellent. The terrain looks very much like it did back in the original, so it's still behind Battlezone 2, nevermind more modern titles. But all things considered, the graphics do a good job today with the update. The gameplay is as rich as ever. Multiplayer is now handled through Steam within the game, which keeps things nice and simple, with all the old options. A bomber DM is still a thrill after all these years.

If you are someone who's never played the original and are wondering whether you should buy this, well don't expect it to look fresh. The developers of this update have done an incredible job hauling parts of the game into the 2010s, but there are engine limitations. Firefights are limited to a few hundred meters in distance, and don't expect detailed ballistics or other physics.

The real joy of Battlezone, however, was always its gameplay, and its blend of FPS and RTS that has never really been replicated since. In each mission you will be dogfighting and base building, often at the same time. A selection of ships can be built, each of which offer different benefits, and you can kit them out with a variety of weapons. Your resources ("biometal") are gathered by Scavengers which have an annoying habit of wandering off into dangerous areas and so need to be constantly protected. Two single-player campaigns are included, so there's a hefty chunk of content for someone who has no plans to dabble in multiplayer.

At the price, this game still delivers eighteen years after its original release, whether you're looking for something new or a satisfying hit of nostalgia. Buy it.

When someone asks me what my favorite game is. or what the best game i ever played was,

To this day I can remember it all.

Some of my best memories are of playing this with my dad and his friends and the journey it took me on as i developed my skills and mindset towards becoming Better and better,  Every match utilized a different  strategy there were so many different vehicles and weapons loadouts you could use that it provided endless challenge and excitement Even though I lost almost every match,

Just as the year ended I donned a New mantle that would come to be my gamertag(ReaperX2000).

 Moments before the new millennium I defeated My father and his friends in a brutal day wrecker victory I built and ammased an army of scouts and an armory quickly hunting down my opponents by carefully placing my troops i ejected so i could overlook the enemy base, launching 2 day wreckers onto seperate targets so the blasts would overlap and cause the most  widespread havoc, 

I waited with my sniper prone trained on whatever red dot i could find as the bombs reached the peak of thier arc i waited anxiously counting down the moments before they would be in range, as they approached just above his base i took the shot sniping one of his scavengers to draw his attention.Perfect, Just as he had time to turn around the bombs dropped destroy his entire offensive wing most of his scavengers and almost all of the buildings lay in critical condition.

"Time to send in the dogs." I ordered my wing of scouts to attack his recycler, it was a crushing blow, as the scouts many miniguns quickly lay waste to what was left of Dads installer buddy.  I quickly ordered my scavengers and a couple defense turrets into the area to collect the salvage, It was time to take on the real threat, Dad himself.

My attack had been successful but in order to accomplish this task i had left myself open to attack at my original base, Fortunately i had already tucked my recyler away in a different geyser, calling it and the constructor it had built i quickly began raiseng defences for my new base, i built several powerplants and guntowers surrounding and plugging the perrimiter turrets,

 I had recyled most of my scouts and sent a few to scout for the enemy repurposing all the metal i could find into tanks and walkers, and of course switching to my own walker with my favorite choice of weapons,(Flash & Mag <3) Dad had already utilized the time to construct his own army of tanks but he lacked defensive structures, With my earlier attack run i had gained advantage by collectiong far more scrap far quicker, He put up a good fight, Our tanks clashed in a battle of explosions for what seemed like an hour. But in the end my resources allowed me the victory, Sending in wave after wave of tanks as i established defenses on his doorstep to reclaim my lost scrap, Eventually he lost out and I claimed Sweet Sweet Victory.

This victory would be the driving force to push me to succeed in any and every video game,Memories of the different odds i have overcome would give me the confidence to take on any new challenge,And the theme of this game would place space simulators action and strategy games in a special place in my heart.My 7 Year old Mind would grow to use battlezone as the basis to judge every game upon, And to this day, No game i have ever played,(And I have played ALOT) compares to matches in this game, 

This to me, is simply the best game that was ever made, and seeing it here in steam(WITH MODS!!), remastered beautifully, Leaving the real joy to this game completely untouched, Because it was just so masterfully done the first time. is a dream come true,

I would reccomend this as a 10 Out of 10 But this game is so wonderful it would simply take its score Divide by zero and multiply by infinity, Not only do I reccoment this game, this is THE game I reccomend For gamers at any point in thier lives

22558045.review:
Battlezone is not a casual RTS game. Don't make that mistake coming into this game.  

The game's difficulty is pretty steep on some places forcing you to think about what you need and plan out a good defense and offence. Unlike most RTS ideals where rushing into battle before the AI get's its camp set, you're rewarded for planning out your base and making the right choices for your army. 

The storyline for the game is also really interesting. Each mission opens the storyline up a bit more, not giving you worthless side quests that have no effect on the story.

Now, there are some issues, but you'll have that when dealing with older titles. The Devs have so far been pretty good about hearing everyone out and fixing what they can.

I'd highly recommend this game not just cause the game itself is fun and challenging, but the odds of getting BattleZone 2 being remade the same way is better if you do. To me, BZ2 is the better of the two but this game still has its place on top. 

Hopefully this game gets popular again so that other Devs try their hand at FPS\RTS games, because it's a genre that doesn't get enough love.

Oh mein Gott, hatte gar nicht in Erinnerung, wie hektisch es  da werden kann (ab Level 2). Muss auch zugeben, das ich drei Anläufe benötigte um Level 1 zuschaffen. Im zweiten Level werde ich gerade von den Russen komplett überrannt ... Aktuell bin ich mit der US Seite gestartet um wieder in den Razor zuspringen. 

Das Game selbst spiegelt den typischen US vs RUS Konfikt wieder bei denen es um Ressourcen auf dem Mond und Mars geht. Basenbau kann man sich wie bei C&C vorstellen. Man muss verschiedene Produktionstätten aufbauen und Ressourcen erschliessen, wobei Gysire eine Art Energiequelle darstellen, welche man ab dem zweiten Level kennenlernt.
Geschütztürme , je nach Ressourcenmenge sind auch baubar, genauso wie im späteren Verlauf die schweren Panzereinheiten, wie den Grizzly zb. und und.
Die Recycler sind das A&O wie bei C&C. Ohne Ressourcen wird man gnadenlos überrannt. 
Man kann auch als Inf da rumrennen und die Piloten rausschiessen aus den Fahrzeugen oder aus Geschütztürmen und diese dann entern. Es empfiehlt sich aber immer ein Fahrzeug in der Nähe zuhaben, falls man als Inf da rum rennt. Schießt man einmal daneben ... wird man i.d.R. sofort gejagt und erschossen bzw. überfahren ... die Knappheit von 2 weiteren Kugeln in dem Gewehr lassen da auch nicht soviel Spielraum, wenn man es vergeigt ;)  

Alle Fahrzeuge, welche man bauen kann, kann man auch besetzen.
Im späteren Verlauf der Kampagne oder auch im MP hat man vollen Zugriff auf alle Einheiten, die da noch kommen. Auch eine Art Mechwarrior ist dabei und kostet entsprechend Ressourcen usw. 

Da ich das Spiel auch aus 1998 kenne, es hat sich nix geändert. Es ist ein klasse Remake und bringt mir ...fast 20 Jahre später gleich von Anfang an sehr viel Spaß. Mein Ziel ist es zunächst beide Kampagnen zu absolvieren (US u. Russkie) bevor ich wieder ins MP Gaming da einsteige....etwas eingerostet ist man da dann doch schon ^^

22531172.review:
Let's think about this for a moment here.

The story involves The Cold War cover up where the actual battles took place all over space. Space tank space race. 

The gameplay is an incredibly well thought out combination of a squad based fps shooter with command and conquer-esque rts elements which has only been done just a few times, none of which has come close to Battlezone in execution.

Because let's face it, there is no reason to attempt it again. It was done perfectly the first time and all future attempts will fall short of greatness.

The base building is satisfying as you go from a small recycler to a full-on citadel of gun turrets and mines as you balance a need to finish off the mission as well as keeping your scrap intake moderated so you do not inadvertantly starve yourself of resources. That's where the first-person squad based gameplay comes in. There are a wide variety of different tanks to choose from with a varying degree of playstyles between them, starting from a nimble and weak Scout/Fighter to a slow, powerful Walker/Golem. Bread and butter Tanks to niche fillers such as Rocket Tanks and Bombers to tackle specific situations that may arise as you fight over a planet. No one tank feels completely useless and all feel as if they can be useful in a one-on-one fight if used/maneuvered correctly. If you choose that the fps gameplay isn't exactly your sort of thing, there exists more traditional RTS elements through satellites that give an overhead view of a map where you can micromanage your tanks effectively rather than blow things up yourself.

It is legitimately my favorite game, and now it has an HD remake and runs perfectly on a modern PC.

This game and all it offers deserves a playthrough, because it never got a fair shake when it initially came out. Think about it for a moment, Atari released boatloads of reboots of their old franchises and most of them were terrible because it did not do anything remotely interesting. Along comes another old arcade reboot which served as the antithesis of everything Atari was churning out. It not only features the badass story that hooks you on its sheer craziness, the gameplay has also aged incredibly well.

Infinite recommends, you should play this and experience one of the most unique games to come out of the 90s. As jaded as I've become over video games along comes this one title I fawned over as a child which shows me that yeah, video games are still pretty great, and Battlezone is just as unique and entertaining as the day it came out. 

Battlezone revealed to me that I love video games, and it deserves to be your favorite game, too.

22528312.review:
Really wanted to like this game as a nostalgic lover of Battlezone 2, and if they make a Battlezone 2 redux I will buy it in a heartbeat, but I REALLY don't see the appeal to this one.

I'm about the second Mars mission in and the game is way too micro-managy to understand what I should and shouldn't be doing. The game gave me a Recycler, an Armory, and ONE Geiser to make use of, so I placed a recycler down, then it told me to go check something out and then when I got there the comms told me "Ok, cool, lock it down".

HOW!?
Was I supposed to build an army before going there?
Was I supposed to setup a defense so that in the minute I was gone 5 russkies didn't blow up my recycler?!

This is my problem with this game over Battlezone 2 negating the fact it lacks a further in-depth base-building mechanic; it doesn't help you whatsoever and often failing can result in waiting ~5 minutes for a specific wave of enemies to arrive just to trigger something over and over again.
I feel like i'm missing specific important controls that are vital to me controlling things, like a command view, but the game doesn't even have a full list of keybinds!
The redux devs completely left out all of the important controls (though i'm not sure if even the original had it).

Not to mention this game feels repetitive.
Every mission so far has been: 
-Escort
-Defend from enemy waves, escort.
-Setup base, defenses, defend base, escort.
Personally I just hate escort missions in games overall, especially when the vehicle you are escorting seems to be made of paper mache.

The story seems decent from the first two hours i've played but it really does feel like basic 1960's sci-fi stuff, which is awesome for some people, and dreadfully boring for others.
It's really slow and lacks life.
Battlezone II jumped into the more "character-based" story-telling at just the right time, when it was starting to become a popular thing to do, and is better for it with memorable characters like Braddock, John, Sharbayev, and Cooke.
There's a set-up, an investigation, defense, build-up, and full on attacks with a farily detailed environment.

I realise BZR's setting is based on the fact that it's the 1960's and they've JUST basically landed, so there's not going to be much in the way of detail, but christ the landscapes are boring to look at.

I don't know, I came in expecting an enhanced BZ1 that is also leagues ahead of BZII, but honestly it isn't.
It's certainly enhanced in ways, but the game is too blurry for me to notice unless I downscale 4k to 1080p which completely destroys my performance somehow on my R9 380.

If I had another hour to play before my refund, I would have tried the Russian campaign to see if that makes up for it, but honestly I just want to go play something else.
If Red Oddyssey expansion comes out (they are "discussing it") I may choose to rebuy it and judge the game on that, because that's appearantly the best BZ out there.
But not if I have to shell out extra cash for it, it should have came with the game or had compatibility for it in the first place.

22527863.review:
What an amazing game.  I played the original version for 300+ hours. 

If you've played this before, then you already know how incredible it is and have bought it.

If you haven't, this version of Battlezone is a hybrid FPS/RTS sci-fi tank/battle Cold War simulator... in space. It's every bit as awesome as it sounds. Basically, imagine a really excellent, top-notch RTS with a fantastic interface in which you get to play as one of your own units while directing the battle. It sounds complex, but the UI is so excellent that neither part of the game, the tank simulator or the RTS, loses anything in the translation; it's two first-rate games in one. You play as a pilot who can switch ships and even snipe enemy pilots and take over their vehicles.

I still remember the amazing adventures I had playing this game. The heart-pounding race to escape  a planet about to explode in seconds, being chased by alien superweapons all the way. Escorting my Soviet scientists across a bridge above the fiery lava of Jupiter's moon Io, getting blown out of my tank as it's destroyed by superior American forces, sniping the pilot of an American rocket tank who attacked me, stealing his vehicle and using it to fire upon my unsuspcecting foes, saving my forces. Sneaking into a heavily defended Soviet base on Europa to see where they've hdiden the stolen plans. Being ambushed by Soviet forces on the plains of Venus. They simply don't get any better than this.

The emergent gameplay situations, the enormous tactical flexibility afforded by the strategic layer of the game, the first-rate physics and satisfying gunplay, the huge variety of weapons and vehicles- even nearly 20 years later, this game remains unmatched I truly wish more people would try to rip it off! To try to compare it to some more modern titles if you haven't played this, imagine melding the seamless tactical interface and large-scale battle control of Sins of a Solar Empire with the visceral action and FPS excitement of Call of Duty, plus the open-ended battlefield and branching combat options afforded by Crysis or Far Cry. All with a cool sci-fi story in space. I am not exaggerating. It truly is that good.

And all this before I even get to the beautiful, loving restoration this game has been given!

All of the above refers to the 1998 "vanilla" edition. But in this 98 Redux edition, the game has been given a complete makeover and beautifully brought up to date with care and devotion. The developers really layered on an extra level of polish along with all-new graphics and options for modern PCs. New, Steam-based online multiplayer? Check. Brand new HD graphics and textures? Check? New mod support? Check. In my brief time to date with the new version, AI also feels like it's been improved and bugs have been fixed. It really feels like a whole new game with the excellent graphics update. This is NOT the shovelware, throw-anything-on-Steam junk that most developers throw up onto the Internet when they get an old license- this is the remastered, restored edition, presented with the care and attention that all developers should lavish on a game rerelease. It truly is worth a buy even if you've played this as many hours as I have.

Until then... I'll see you on the Martian battlefields... or the Moon.... or Venus....

22522833.review:
My favorite game apart from maybe Interstate '76, and it's based upon that game's engine anyway. One of the defining games of my childhood and well deserving of this re-release.

Originally released in 1998, this take on Battlezone was itself a re-imagining of the 1980 arcade game. It blended first-person vehicular combat with real-time strategy elements to create a revolutionary hybrid game experience that has only been briefly revisited since, in games such as Sacrifice and Brutal Legend.

In 1952, as the story goes, a meteor shower in the arctic circle brought a previously unknown organic material to Earth. Simultaneously discovered by scientists of both the US and the Soviet Union, this "Bio-Metal" was soon discovered to have the unique ability to remember shapes it had previously assumed. From this material, the superpowers created hovering tanks and weapons centuries ahead of anything they could have otherwise made at the time. They quickly ran out of it, and turned their eyes towards the stars in search of more. In secret, the two nations sent thousand-man armies into space. Thus began a new, hidden chapter of the Cold War- the one too brutal to televise. You will journey to the moon, Mars, Venus and beyond in search of the bio-metal, and the truth of its origins.

You take the role of a soldier of either the Americans' National Space Defense Force, or NSDF, or the Russians' Cosmo Colonist Army, or CCA. You begin most campaign missions, as well as multiplayer strategy matches, with your own tank and a Recycler- at once your core base structure, your resource depository, and a factory that produces all other essential units. It exists in a mobile or deployed state, able to travel (slowly) about until you find a geyser over which to deploy it, whereupon it becomes able to build. You have two resources: scrap, and pilots. The former are gathered by scavengers, autonomous resource-harvesting vehicles built from the Recycler that will wander the map gathering bio-metal scrap, found lying around in fields on most maps, or generated from destroyed vehicles and structures. Controlling these scrap fields and assigning escorts to your scavengers is crucial in more difficult missions, and in multiplayer.

Combat vehicles include nimble scout craft, light and medium tanks, rocket tanks, bombers, and walkers. Defensive units include mobile turrets and artillery that must deploy to fire, as well as minelayers. Offensive vehicles for the most part are fast, turn quickly and can strafe, allowing you to maintain fire on a target while avoiding return fire, though the bombers do not turn quickly and are more adept at long-range strikes on static structures. Combat is fast and chaotic- focused fire can destroy most vehicles in seconds, and battles can involve upwards of twenty tanks at once- more in the campaign. You should quickly master the ability to group your units using Control plus the Function keys, and commanding them to focus-fire individual enemy targets, lest they haphazardly engage multiple enemies at once and lose the advantage of their numbers. The scouts and turrets are built from your Recycler, while the rest are built from your Unit Factory, a more specialized builder vehicle that is also built from the Recycler. If a vehicle is destroyed, including yours, fear not- the pilot will eject, and have the opportunity to return to their base and be put in a new vehicle. While on foot, you are extremely vulnerable, but not defenseless- you have a low-damage plasma gun, as well as a sniper rifle you can use to snipe out the pilot of an enemy vehicle and steal it for yourself. Be wary of enemy pilots in multiplayer!

You may also build a Constructor vehicle from your Recycler that can build fixed structures, such as powerful gun towers, repair and resupply structures, and a communications tower that grants you access to an overhead satellite view in the vein of a traditional RTS. It can also build a barracks- the only way to increase your pilot count. Protect your Constructor well- it's often a priority target for AI enemies, and getting a network of gun towers up is crucial for fending off regular enemy raids in the later campaign missions. You will also want to build an Armory, a third mobile base vehicle that builds and launches repair, ammo and weapon pickups, as it is your only means of repairing structures and allows you to resupply in the field, as well as launch bombs on enemy bases.

You can command your units either by looking directly at them and pressing the space bar or by selecting them using the number keys from a list. Units are organized into offensive, defensive, utility, with an extra section for available navigation beacons, which also function as cameras when selected, to give you remote viewing of that location. Offensive units have the most diverse range of orders- they can be commanded to move to a specific location, attack or defend your current target, follow you, defend a key friendly, or to move to a selected nav beacon, as well as to get repairs or ammunition, or to recycle- refunding a portion of scrap used in their construction, as well as returning their pilots to your global pilot count- this is good, because you have a finite cap of 30 pilots per level and they cannot be replaced. This works both ways- target enemy pilots to deny the AI access to replacement units- I think. The computer probably cheats on both scrap and pilots, and they most certainly can spawn near-infinite waves of harassing attacks on your base. It works in multiplayer though.

Aside from the two story campaigns, there are a variety of multiplayer modes, including deathmatch, strategy, and "MPI", a form of co-op strategy versus AI. This Redux includes extensive Steam Workshop support- you can download maps on the fly even in-game. It also includes updated models and visual effects, trading cards, achievements, and other niceties- aside from running very smoothly on modern systems, more so then it ever did in the old days. However, it is a essentially a straight re-release, and does not attempt to address any of the game's existing shortcomings- save the netcode, of course.

You are limited, for example, to only ten units of each type, since that's as far as the number keys go, as well as the hard pilot cap of 30. The AI is single-minded at best and suicidal at worst, with frequent issues with pathfinding, often getting stuck trying to scale inclines the player would have no trouble at all with. Scavengers are completely incapable of not only defending themselves but even of reacting to being attacked, and will continue on their merry way scavenging in the face of certain destruction. Artillery units will fire at will regardless of the risk of hitting your own forces and cannot be set to hold their fire. Your offensive units also require careful management ot get the most out of their attacks. The walkers are also so painfully slow that their use in most campaign missions is extremely limited- its entirely possible to finish CCA Mission 6, for example, without the use of the three Golems you are given. Most campaign missions also have only one or two safe methods of completion, with very little room for experimental tactics.

However, most of these flaws are attributable to the limitations of the original game engine, and and while they are even more glaringly obvious all these years later, there is something to be said for bringing the game to Steam and a new audience as is, the way we enjoyed it 18 years ago, and it is certainly easier to forgive then a brand new game with these same flaws. Battlezone was something completely new and any problems it had were excusable in the face of how much fun I had with it, and it was a great pleasure to revisit this landmark title in both my young life and the history of PC gaming. I urge newcomers and old hands, shooter and strategy fans alike to pick this one up. You will not be disappointed.

22519413.review:
So, here's the thing. There are far too few genre mix games like this. Uprising and Battlezone are among the first, and also the finest out there. Here's a game where you not only fly hovertanks, but you can hop out and snipe enemy pilots from their vehicles to steal them! The campaign is quite long and does a good job at providing an interesting story, especially for a game this early.

There were some crippling bugs at launch but even a day later many, if not most issues have been fixed.

This re-release is definitely worth the price of admission: The devs not only made the game work on new PCs, but they actually added new features like a completely new rendering engine based on Ogre, multiplayer lobby support via Steam, and even Steam Workshop for mods. You can even play community-made multiplayer coop missions together.

Should you get this? Yes. Yes you should.

22518601.review:
I have fond memmories of this game, played it for countless hours back in school...long time ago :) 

It is a perfect, genre connecting mix of RTS, base building, simulation and tactical gameplay. The game was years ahead of its time. Unfortunately they don't make games like this nowadays. It's a pity since with todays technology and graphics, this would be an instant hit. 

The campaign(s) are well written and fully voiced. You play a commander of either the US or Soviet forces in a war for resources in our solar system, mostly on the various moons of our planets. But it is not just your standard conflict of US vs Soviet, there will be a surprise in the campaign...nuff said. :) 

The UI is innovative and context sensitive, which is also absolutely a must for a tactical and strategic game like this, given the orders you have to provide on the fly. Even after so many years developers still can't get UI right and given the complexity of BattleZone, it is a refreshing surprise that a 18 year old game nails it spot on.   

If you think that the price is too high for such an old game, let me tell you it is totally worth it. This overhaul comes with completly new models of vehicles, buidlings, surfaces and sky-boxes. It is not just a fake "HD overhaul". It ain't 2016 graphics but it is surprisingly pretty for a game from 1998.

Two thumbs up!

22513590.review:
Battlezone is a game that was way ahead of its time when it was first released in 1998. It seamlessly blended FPS and RTS gameplay in a way that has yet to be matched by another game (apart from the sequel: BZII). Not only can the player build and direct units in battle, but they can participate directly in those battles themselves.

I remember playing Battlezone consistently for several years, until I got my hands on Battlezone II: Combat Commander. My grades suffered because of this obsession. To see that it had been remastered was exciting. At only 15 dollars (20% off sale), it was an easy impulse purchase.

Rebellion has done a swell job of remastering this game. The gameplay is essentially the same as it was in 1998 (apart from bug fixes). Everything just feels right. With the substantial graphical overhaul, the style of the game has been neatly retained. There is no dissonance between my nostalgic memories of the original and the improved fidelity of this remaster.

The story is an incredibly captivating Cold War era sci-fi alternate history. The Americans and the Soviets battle across the solar system in a race to gather "bio-metal" and to discover its mysterious origin. There are two campaigns; one from the American perspective, and the other from the Soviet perspective. 

Rebellion has also bolstered the mod support of the game with Steam Workshop integration and mod tools. Mods from the original can also be ported into the remaster. I'm eager to see what the community can do with this new opportunity.

I look forward to playing this for years to come.

PS: the original cheat codes still work!

22512238.review:
So I'm going to start with the criticisms first.

The "Joystick" controls are not very good.  You have a bunch of default settings for some Joystick types, XBox Controller and Steam Controller but none of them are re-bindable and a prime example is the self-destruct button is bound to X.  There seems to be little support for modern HOTAS joysticks like the X55 (and I enjoyed playing this game back in 1998 with my Throttle joystick, I would love to be able to do it again). I would note though that keyboard bindings are fully configurable.

I also forgot how annoying the *beep* *beep* noise is when an enemy approaches, and firing this up near midnight the misses wasn't too happy with the annoying noises.  Would be nice to have more options to turn that stuff off.

HOWEVER other than this, really it's the same great game that is was 18 years ago but looking a bit sharper. The only thing that hasn't transfered well is the FMV sequences but that is to be expected for a retro title like this.

22512199.review:
You know what is the saddest thing of Battlezone Redux? That they do not make games like this anymore.  I will try now to stay away from my 18 years long nostalgia and do an accurate review.

Battlezone is a mix between RTS and FPS/Simulation, as you will probably know. The gameplay mechanics are very well integrated into this concept: While piloting your hovertank through several solar system worlds, you can control your production ships, combat units, defense, support vessels.... Anything simply with your numbers, tab and space. It is a system that requires a bit of playing to learn but, once you do, it becomes really intuitive. 

From an strategy point of view, you have a very limited number of units in play. That is, 10 offense, 10 defense, 10 support. With those, you must overplay your opponents to actually win the game. If you combine that with limited resources (in the form of biometal) and ships that, when destroyed, become a little ammount of biometal, you have the key for very dinamic multiplayer games. A failed attack against the enemy base may mean that your enemy will get extra resoureces, while you will loose yours. Tough decission, right?

The simulation and FPS system is a combination of your piloting skills, the tank you have and how you outfit it, specially in the latest game. The best definition of it is "ground based dogfight": To pilot a hovertank that flies at about 3 feet from the ground, jumping over the obstacles and maybe flying over your enemy to rain death on him... That's majestic. Of course many players will feel confused with the handling, as this game represent very well the "hovering" mechanics... but that's part of the fun. A direct hit may send your tank flying away, and you may need a moment to retake control of it. 

About the rework: I love it... but the nostalgic kid inside of me tell me "that's not my game!". I really like how it looks: the new models, explosions, particle and light effects... It is really a HUGE improvement, profiting the potential that average computers nowadays can offer. But old players as I may find it... strange. The feeling is the same than when you watch your favourite movie dubbed in a different language. It may be very good but... it's not the same. 

And about the campaigns:

The campaign story is amazing.  New players may find it linear (yes, it is) and a bit topical for the first 2 or 3 missions. All this changes when you find, in Mars, an alien relic... that relates directly to an ancient human civilisation. And I will not spoil anything there, but if you like mithology as I do... You will be mind-blowed. Specially when the real enemy shows up in the end!

My recommendation for new players: Give battlezone redux a try. The mix of RTS and FPS may feel strange at first, but when you get a handle on it you will be amazed of the epicness it can handle! Deploy your recycler and get those scavengers! Get the biometal while defending them with a few scouts! Get your defenses, but move closer to a new biometal deposit! Get your army, and lead them into battle, charge against the enemy while the bomber's missiles fly just over your head! And find out no pilot, not even you, is good enough to win every battle alone!

Battlezone is a relic, one that has not been repeated since its sequel "BZ2 battle commander"... so try it. It is really worth the money.

Scavenge the battlefields for crucial bio-metal, deploy powerful defenses, construct advanced facilities and escalate each battle to an epic confrontation.

22510037.review:
Battlezone has always had a special place in my heart since I first piloted a Grizzly tank, on Mars, with an army at my back, facing an enemy just as powerful as I was. The concept is flawless- a masterful FPS and an intuitive RTS cleanly blended together in a hovertank space shooter. Remastering this timeless classic is one of the greatest revitalizations I've come across.

The game offers a unique environment where standardized FPS elements are challenged and redefined. I am a huge fan of ammo shared between all of your weapons. Combined with the mobile, dynamic RTS that forces you to make decisions based on the type of terrain you're in and what the enemy is building, just like any RTS. However, the only thing I find lacking in the entire game is the RTS itself as I personally find it quite simplified, but in exchange for the complexity of strategy there is a first-person combat experience to steal the focus from.

As a modder for the original game from 1998, I am enthusiastic about the capabilities the Redux has, especially Steam Workshop support. The unified and proven system Workshop offers will give my creations more exposure than ever before, something I look forward to and intend to make the best of.

The game has survived eighteen years of existence. Some said Battlezone was "the best game you've never played". With the Redux, that will change. Battlezone is better than ever before, and it is destined to bring both old and new players back to the front lines.

- blue banana

22507938.review:
An old gem from my childhood, Battlezone manages to perfectly merge RTS and FPS elements creating a kind of field commander experience that has yet to be effectively reproduced in the 18 years since its inception. Coupled with one of the best stories ever to be written for a video game, this is a game you absolutely can NOT miss out on.

As for this specific re-release, it's as well done as anyone could ask for a game that's nearly 20 years old. Rebellion has seamlessly integrated the game into Steam's workshop and brought the graphics engine up to speed (or close enough for my liking, anyway) for modern systems, and brought everything into high resolution since we no longer run 640x480 on our systems any more.

I cannot thank Rebellion enough for this!

However, I must venture a warning. If you see this game and automatically think "Activision? CALL OF DUTY!" you're in the wrong market. When this game first came out, Activision made GOOD games. Do NOT buy this game if you're looking for a call of duty-esque game.

See everyone on the Moon, or Mars, or wherever you dare face me.

22507347.review: Battlezone 98 has always remained one of my all time favorite games.  It was before it's time, coming on to the scene during a period when Mechwarrior 2 was still fresh in the minds of PC gaming.  It combined RTS and first person (both vehicle and on foot) in a really fascinating package of the secret war between the US and USSR over the mysterious bio-metal that was spread throughout the solar system.  The RTS aspect was solid and setting up bases worked well in that you never left the action, the game was seamless.  Thanks to Rebellion, we now have Redux, which updates the game and brings it out of the shadows again (there has been an active community around this game for years!), and the various enhancements along with release on Steam will give this gem another shot in the modern gaming world.  Absolutely recommended!
